newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU trade ministers meet to map out Singapore plans.
newsitem.headline: EU trade ministers meet to map out Singapore plans.

text.p: European Union ministers on Tuesday began gathering to finalise plans for the 15-nation bloc's role in the world's biggest trade meeting in December.

With the World Trade Organisation ministerial meeting in Singapore now less then two months away, some diplomats are concerned that the European Commission -- the EU's executive -- may have fallen behind schedule.
"We probably should be closer to a common position than we are," one senior diplomat said. "Today is almost our last chance to get things settled."
Diplomats said while there were no "showstoppers", concern was mounting at Britain's insistance on the EU raising the issue of labour rights at the Singapore meeting.
The other 14 EU nations agree with Trade Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan that it should be kept off the main agenda.
Brittan is due on Tuesday to make a presentation of what he believes the EU should take to Singapore, after which trade ministers from the 15 nations will state their positions.
Among the matters to be discussed are trade and investment, trade and the environment and trade and development, including new proposals to help the world's poorest countries.

Diplomats said the meeting was likely to be split among north/south lines, with the former arguing for more trade liberalisation and the latter for protectionism -- particularly in agriculture and textiles.
